title: Edge Coloring
content:
An **edge coloring** of the complete graph K_n with k colors assigns a color from Fin k to each edge (pair of vertices).

We represent edges as ordered pairs (i, j) ∈ Fin n × Fin n. Symmetric colorings satisfy c(i,j) = c(j,i).

title: Symmetric Coloring
content:
A coloring is **symmetric** if c(i,j) = c(j,i) for all vertices i, j.

This ensures our edge colorings are well-defined for undirected graphs, where {i,j} = {j,i}.

title: Monochromatic Clique
content:
A set S of vertices forms a **monochromatic clique** in color col if every edge within S has color col:

∀ i, j ∈ S, i ≠ j → c(i,j) = col

This is the key structure Ramsey theory guarantees will exist for large enough graphs.

title: Monochromatic Triangle
content:
A **monochromatic triangle** in color col is three distinct vertices a, b, c where all three edges have the same color:

c(a,b) = c(b,c) = c(a,c) = col

Triangles (K₃) are the simplest cliques and play a central role in Ramsey theory.

title: Ramsey Number R(3,n)
content:
**R(3,n)** is the smallest m such that any 2-coloring of K_m has either:
- A monochromatic triangle in color 0 (red), OR
- A monochromatic K_n in color 1 (blue)

Intuitively: how large must a graph be to force either a red triangle or a blue clique of size n?
mathContext: R(3,3) = 6 is the classical result. For larger n, Shearer (1983) showed R(3,n) ≤ Cn²/log n.

title: Ramsey Number R(3,3,n)
content:
**R(3,3,n)** is the smallest m such that any 3-coloring of K_m has either:
- A monochromatic triangle in color 0 (red), OR
- A monochromatic triangle in color 1 (blue), OR
- A monochromatic K_n in color 2 (green)

The key difference: TWO colors can now be triangle-free, not just one!
mathContext: Having two triangle-free colors dramatically increases the threshold. Alon-Rödl showed R(3,3,n) ≍ n³(log n)^O(1).

title: Shearer's Bound
content:
**Shearer (1983):**

R(3,n) ≤ C · n² / log n

for some constant C > 0.

This is the key upper bound for the 2-color case. The log factor in the denominator comes from probabilistic constructions of triangle-free graphs.

title: R(3,n) Lower Bound
content:
**Lower Bound:**

R(3,n) ≥ c · n² / (log n)²

The lower bound is slightly weaker than the upper bound (extra log factor). The exact asymptotics of R(3,n) remain an open problem!

title: Alon-Rödl Upper Bound
content:
**Alon-Rödl (2005):**

R(3,3,n) ≤ C · n³ · (log n)^k

for some constants C > 0 and k ∈ ℕ.

The **cubic** growth in n (vs quadratic for R(3,n)) is the key to the divergence result.

title: Alon-Rödl Lower Bound
content:
**Alon-Rödl (2005):**

R(3,3,n) ≥ c · n³ / (log n)^k

for some constants c > 0 and k ∈ ℕ.

Together with the upper bound, this establishes R(3,3,n) ≍ n³(log n)^O(1).

title: Ratio Tends to Infinity
content:
**The Divergence Condition:**

For every M > 0, there exists N such that for all n ≥ N:

R(3,3,n) / R(3,n) > M

This is the formal statement that the ratio grows without bound.

title: Main Theorem
content:
**Erdős Problem #553: SOLVED**

R(3,3,n) / R(3,n) → ∞ as n → ∞.

**Proof sketch:**
- R(3,3,n) ≥ cn³/(log n)^k
- R(3,n) ≤ Cn²/log n
- Ratio ≥ (c/C) · n · (log n)^(1-k) → ∞

title: Triangle-Free Turán Bound
content:
**Turán's Theorem for Triangles:**

A triangle-free graph on n vertices has at most n²/4 edges.

This bound is achieved by the complete bipartite graph K_{n/2, n/2}.

In a 2-coloring, one color must be triangle-free, so it has ≤ n²/4 edges.

title: Two Triangle-Free Graphs
content:
**Key Insight:**

Two triangle-free graphs together can have up to n²/2 edges (double what one can have).

In a 3-coloring:
- Color 0 and Color 1 can each be triangle-free
- Combined, they can cover n²/2 edges
- This leaves only n²/2 - n²/2 = 0 edges for the clique color at the boundary

This extra flexibility is why R(3,3,n) grows faster than R(3,n).

title: Off-Diagonal Ramsey R(s,t)
content:
The **off-diagonal Ramsey number** R(s,t) is the smallest m such that any 2-coloring of K_m has either:
- A red clique of size s, OR
- A blue clique of size t

R(3,n) is exactly the off-diagonal Ramsey number R(3,n).

title: Classical R(3,3) = 6
content:
**Classical Result:**

R(3,3) = 6.

Any 2-coloring of K₆ has a monochromatic triangle. This is the simplest non-trivial Ramsey number.

The proof is a beautiful case analysis or clever counting argument.

title: Asymptotic Equivalence
content:
**Notation: f ≍ g**

f ≍ g means there exist constants c₁, c₂ > 0 and N such that:

c₁ · g(n) ≤ f(n) ≤ c₂ · g(n)  for all n ≥ N

This captures 'same order of magnitude up to constants'.

title: Erdős-Sós Generalization
content:
**Open Question:**

For r < s triangle colors, does

R(3,...,3,n) / R(3,...,3,n) → ∞?
(s 3's)     (r 3's)

The pattern suggests yes: each additional triangle color adds a power of n to the threshold.

title: Summary
content:
**Erdős Problem #553: SOLVED**

- Question: Does R(3,3,n)/R(3,n) → ∞?
- Answer: YES (Alon-Rödl 2005)
- Key: R(3,3,n) ≍ n³(log)^O(1) vs R(3,n) ≪ n²/log n
- Intuition: Two triangle-free colors allow much denser edge structures
- Ratio growth: ~n times logarithmic factors
